author: gcolvin
content: My proposal attempts to resolve the governance issues, by clarifying that the Editors and the Core Devs are distinct organizations with their own governance and areas of responsibility.  And it provides a fail-safe for the core developers -- they are allowed to push PRs past the editors.

author: gcolvin
content: Having resolved the governance we can worry about how to arrange the repos to best support our work.  If we can't resolve the governance issues we have bigger problems.

author: gcolvin
content: It's technical English.  Spelling, grammar, Markdown syntax, citation format.  The fields of the header the bot uses.  Basic format like having an Abstract and a Security section.  Sequential document numbers.  These are things that don't need to be at all different for ERCs and EIPs, and that for the most part nobody but the Editors cares to manage.  If the Editors are doing much more than that we have overstepped our role.

author: gcolvin
content: A serious problem has been that Core work can be (and has been) delayed by small disagreements between the Author and the Editors or our bots.  So the Editors can wind up with a veto over the Core Developers publishing their work.  I've proposed to let them override the veto.

author: gcolvin
content: So nothing in my actual proposal requires a split -- it just cleans up things like link rules that I and others have been complaining about for a long time, and tries to clarify the responsibilities and powers of the Editors and our users.

author: gcolvin
content: The proposal does make it easier for any person or group to publish their proposals as EIPs while doing most of the editing in their own repo.  I've informally laid out a refactoring that moves working drafts into separate WGEIP and WGERC repos so that the original EIPs repo can remain as the place where the Editors work together, and the Core Devs can manage their docs and workflow in the WGEIP repo.

author: gcolvin
content: I think something like this meets the needs that I have been hearing.

author: _shemnon
content:
> It seems like you want to kick the ERCs out of the EIPs

If that was the goal we wouldn't be going through the processes, we would just ask the EF for the admin rights to the repository.  I want two different healthy processes running at the end of this.

Having two fundamentally different workflows in the same repository presents programming problems for the bots.  There will be too may "if EIP do this if ERC do that" clauses that will slip into each others workflows at some point.  And if we want to add even more gatekeeping relating to client preparedness (don't progress this EIP past CFI until there is a link to each client's PR or a link to a releases with it implemented, for example) then that's more headache to keep ERCs out of it and whole swaths of EIP 1 that is specialized for one set of working groups.

And then the working groups, they will be significantly different on the ERC side.  I don't expect standing working groups, and WG membership mediations could become a task the editors may need to wade into for hot community ERCs, especially separating out contributors with real value to add from the people only looking for a trophy seat to add to their resume and conference bio.

author: _shemnon
content: These concerns are too divergant to keep in one repo.
